insights: The transcript corpus is the operational backbone: thousands of meetings, heavy coordination load, and broad topic coverage (strategy, ops, hiring, tooling).
“Work” contains substantial personal/health/family signals; Personal/Family areas are almost empty, so work meetings are functioning as the universal inbox.
There’s a consistent “follow‑up gap”: decisions/risk are discussed often, but explicit action capture is sparse.
Tooling friction (Notion vs Airtable, Premiere complaints) shows up as a recurring theme, suggesting process drag.
The index is the lens for most analysis, but it has integrity issues (FTS/content mismatch) and limited file‑type coverage.
Work ↔ Personal: personal themes exist inside work meetings rather than in their intended areas; this explains the “empty Personal/Family” artifacts.
System ↔ Work: ingestion spikes and FTS drift indicate tooling/indexing decisions shape what is visible and trustworthy.
Meetings ↔ Ops friction: high meeting volume + schedule‑slip language implies operational overload and context switching costs.
Content ↔ Tools: transcripts themselves contain requirements/specs for tooling changes (e.g., Airtable migration).
. Build a decision/action extraction layer from transcripts. High impact, directly addresses the “follow‑up gap.”
recommendations: respect privacy boundaries and access controls
